title: 105_hr2973
content: The Act titled "Sportfishing and Boating Improvement Act of 1997" amends the 1950 Act related to fish restoration and management projects. It also includes provisions for outreach and communications programs. The 1950 Act is amended to define terms and include provisions for outreach and communications programs to improve communications with anglers and boaters. The 1950 Act is amended to include provisions for outreach programs to improve communications with anglers, boaters, and the public regarding fishing and boating opportunities, conservation, and safety. The State allocation percentage is increased from 12.5% to 15%. The Sportfishing and Boating Improvement Act of 1997 amends the 1950 Act to increase the State allocation percentage from 12.5% to 15%. It also establishes a National Outreach and Communications Program within one year of enactment, in cooperation with the Sport Fishing and Boating Partnership Council, to develop a national plan for outreach and communications. The National Outreach and Communications Program, established under the Sportfishing and Boating Improvement Act of 1997, provides guidance for outreach programs and the establishment of a national program. The Secretary may fund programs through grants or contracts with states or private entities. The plan must be reviewed periodically, at least once every 3 years. Within 12 months of completing the national plan, a State Outreach and Communications Program must be implemented. After completing the national plan, a State must develop an outreach and communications program by consulting with stakeholders and establishing priorities for implementation. SEC. 4. CLEAN VESSEL ACT FUNDING. Section 4(b) of the 1950 Act is amended to allocate $42,500,000 annually for fiscal years 1998 through 2003. $15,000,000 goes to State recreational boating safety programs, $10,000,000 to qualified projects under the Clean Vessel Act, and another $10,000,000 for unspecified use. The Secretary of the Interior has $10,000,000 available for qualified projects under the Sportfishing and Boating Improvement Act of 1997, and $7,500,000 for the national outreach and communications program. Funds cannot replace general appropriations and must be used for authorized purposes only. The Secretary of the Interior has funds available for specific purposes under the Sportfishing and Boating Improvement Act of 1997. Unobligated amounts after 3 years will be transferred to the Secretary of Transportation for State recreational boating safety programs. Funds for the national outreach and education program must be used within 2 fiscal years. The Secretary of the Interior has funds available for specific purposes under the Sportfishing and Boating Improvement Act of 1997. Unobligated amounts after 3 years will be transferred to the Secretary of Transportation for State recreational boating safety programs. Additionally, funds for the national outreach and education program must be used within 2 fiscal years. SEC. 5. BOATING INFRASTRUCTURE. The section aims to provide funds to states for developing and maintaining public facilities for transient nontrailerable recreational vessels. It also includes provisions for national and state surveys to assess the adequacy and quality of facilities providing access to recreational waters for all sizes of recreational boats. The section provides funds to states for public boat access facilities for recreational vessels. States must conduct surveys to assess access needs, with an exception for states with existing adequate plans. Funding for surveys can come from allocated amounts. The section allocates funding for states to develop plans for public boat access facilities for nontrailerable recreational vessels. States must conduct surveys to assess access needs, and within 6 months of submitting a survey, a state may submit a plan for construction, renovation, and maintenance of facilities. The Secretary of the Interior administers a grant program for matching grants. The Secretary of the Interior administers a grant program for matching grants to states for constructing, renovating, or maintaining public facilities for transient nontrailerable recreational vessels, with priority given to specific projects. The grant program administered by the Secretary of the Interior prioritizes projects for constructing, renovating, or maintaining public facilities for transient nontrailerable recreational vessels. These vessels are defined as recreational boats over 26 feet in length used primarily for pleasure or leased for enjoyment by others. The program aims to increase the availability of facilities through public/private partnerships and innovative proposals. The definition of "public facilities for transient nontrailerable recreational vessels" includes structures like mooring buoys and day-docks available to the general public. The term "State" refers to various regions within the United States. This section will be effective starting October 1, 1997. SEC. 6. AQUATIC RESOURCES TRUST FUND. Excise Tax Amendments and Trust Fund Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, changing dates from 1999 to 2005. Trust Fund Section 9503 is amended to limit transfers to $60,000,000 annually starting in 1998. Section 9504 is also amended. Section 9504 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change dates from 1998 to 2005. Additionally, Section 13106 of title 46, United States Code is amended to specify the expenditure for State recreational boating safety programs. The amendment specifies the allocation of funds for the Coast Guard's boating safety program under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. $5,000,000 is designated annually for this purpose, with funds remaining available until expended. The Secretary is required to publish an annual report on the expenditure of these funds. The Secretary must annually publish a detailed report in the Federal Register on the projects, programs, and activities funded under this subsection.
